Award.AwardTitle: Composite Methodologies Towards Quantitative Predictions across the Periodic Table
Award.AbstractNarration:
Angela Wilson of the University of North Texas is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Method program in the Chemistry Division to continue developing a novel ab initio composite method - the correlation consistent Composite Approach (ccCA) - that mimics the accuracy achieved by highly correlated methods such as CCSD(T), but at much reduced computational cost. The ccCA methodology is extraordinarily robust, and has been successfully applied not only to ground states, but also to excited states and transition states, to diverse chemistries, from weak interactions to highly energetic species, proving useful for both single reference and multireference wavefunction-based problems and for both metal and nonmetal compounds. The project goal is to develop and apply a family of composite approaches that can be used across the entire periodic table, thereby providing composite methodologies that are applicable to broad classes of problems and chemical systems.

Energetic data is often the most critical information needed for rational analysis and design of molecular species and materials. However, one of the long-standing challenges in computational chemistry is in achieving accurate energetics, due to the limited size of molecules that can be studied routinely with high accuracy. The challenges become even more substantial for heavier main group, transition metal, and f-block metal species, where the evolution of practical, high accuracy approaches is much less developed. Ab initio composite strategies have provided a reliable means to predict accurate energetic properties for molecules through the 3d main group. This project addresses these issues by developing strategies for prediction of energetic properties of heavier elements, with application to chemical species and processes of relevance to environmental sustainability. The methods are widely disseminated to the broader scientific community through inclusion in popular computational chemistry software packages. The Wilson group provides scientific training to a broad range of students, from high school to doctoral.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the increasing emphasis upon sustainability, chemistry is once again at the forefront of a major national scientific challenge. The design of sustainable chemical species and processes, the development of renewable energy resources, and the design of new, more efficient catalysts to the replacement of critical resources with looming shortages, are but a few examples. A number of these problems are ones where the pressing need requires a rapid solution, indeed within the next decade. Fast technological solutions entail the partnering of experiment and modern high performance computation and simulation, with the latter playing a major role in designing replacement materials (e.g., for noble metal catalysts or rare earth electronics) or providing valuable insight such as interpretation of experiment, understanding species that are difficult to study experimentally, to the prediction of properties of molecules that have not yet been made. 

To address these major scientific challenges, energetic data is often the most critical information needed for rational analysis and design of molecular species and materials. However, one of the longstanding challenges in computational chemistry is in achieving accurate energetics, due to the computational expense (computer time, memory, and disk space) of the methods required, thus severely limiting the size of molecules that can be studied routinely with high accuracy. The challenges become even more substantial for heavier, main group, transition and f-block metal species, where the evolution of practical, high accuracy approaches is much less developed.

Intellectual Merit. In this work, a family of quantum mechanical approaches was designed to provide energetic (thermodynamic) predictions of broad classes of molecules.  Included in this work was the design of an efficient, novel computational approach was designed to describe f-block species, elements for which supply chain constrictions have become increasingly acute for the U.S., yet the elements are widely used in cars, cells phones, display devices, magnets, stealth technology, and many other technologies. 

Broader Impact. The research enabled high school, undergraduate, and graduate students to gain experience in both method development and applications, preparing manuscripts for publication, and presenting sponsored research results at scientific conferences, thus preparing these early career computational chemists to thrive in their future scientific careers. The methodology developed will be implemented in popular computational chemistry packages, enabling utility by the broader scientific community.

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2017
Modified by: Robert E Maleczka
